awd_titl_txt: Office of Naval Research (ONR) Support of the National Center for Atmospheric Research Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
This is the Cooperative Support Agreement under the NSF/UCAR Cooperative Agreement to support the National Center for Atmospheric Research activities funded by the Office of Naval Research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This report represents projects that are funded by the Office of Naval Research (ONR) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). The projects aimed to provide precise atmospheric measurements to enhance our understanding of weather phenomena over data-scarce regions like the oceans. The main focus was on the fabrication and deployment of the Airborne Vertical Atmospheric Profiling System (AVAPS) Dropsonde System on Navy NP-3D aircraft.

Intellectual Merit

The AVAPS Dropsonde System measures critical atmospheric parameters—temperature, pressure, humidity, and wind—through high-resolution, in situ profiling as sondes descend from aircraft. These data are crucial for characterizing weather systems with high precision. The projects involved fabricating and rigorously testing various system components, including telemetry receiver cards, sonde interface cards, and GPS modules. These systems underwent extensive testing across temperature ranges to ensure reliable operation under diverse conditions.

The Dropsonde System’s capability to release up to eight sondes simultaneously allows for detailed spatial characterization of the atmosphere, enhancing the study of phenomena such as tropical storms, winter storms, and atmospheric rivers. This system offers a tool of unprecedented precision, supporting Navy research and broader atmospheric science goals. Data collected will feed into near-real-time models, improving weather predictions, especially over remote regions where traditional observation is limited.

Broader Impacts

The deployment of the AVAPS Dropsonde System offers significant societal benefits. By delivering real-time atmospheric data to the North American Global Telecommunications Service, the system supports various weather models and assists scientists in analyzing and predicting severe weather events. This real-time data capability is especially valuable for monitoring conditions over the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, where the potential for severe storms and atmospheric rivers can impact coastal regions along the U.S. West Coast.

The project also advances collaboration between NSF NCAR and the Navy, fostering knowledge exchange and enabling real-time data sharing for academic and operational use. Dropsonde data will be accessible to the global community through the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), promoting open access to valuable meteorological data. Additionally, by expanding the usage of the AVAPS Dropsonde System, the project indirectly supports the transfer of dropsonde manufacturing technology, ensuring a steady production supply for research institutions worldwide.

In summary, the AVAPS Dropsonde System project enhances atmospheric research capabilities by enabling high-resolution profiling of weather systems, advancing our ability to monitor and predict extreme weather. This capability is essential for protecting communities and infrastructure, demonstrating a meaningful contribution to science and society.
